messageBody:
OK, I can accept #33+#25 for FORCE and NORTH. In fact, for me this
will be the only use I make of #33, so it's easy to simply memorize
that this ligature is used for for "or" and "oar".

Regarding Choice 1 vs. Choice 2, I could be persuaded in either
direction. I guess the important question is this: is there any accent
for which one of these choices would seem extremely unnatural?

Ted


On Nov 9, 2007 11:53 AM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>
>
> > I vote for Choice 1. After all, I'm interested in reform--even in
> > reforming the reform alphabet! Even so, I'm willing to submit to the
> > will of the majority on this one.
>
> I don't think this is a matter for ballots, any more than for bullets.
> Rather, it's a question of persuasion. As I keep saying, there is a
> degree of arbitrariness in the choice, not least because many people
> don't clearly use either Eat or It in the NEAR set, but a vowel somewhere
> between.
>
> The argument for Choice 1 (It, Et, Foot) is that more individuals speak
> that way. The argument for Choice 2 (Eat, Ate, Ooze) is that more accents
> use it and it is the historical one: it's no accident that Orthodox writes
> "rear" not "rirr" and "square" not "squerr".
>
>
> > Now let's turn to NORTH and FORCE. According to the handout you cited,
> > "In both standard accents, the FORCE words, historically distinct from
> > NORTH words, have now become or are now in the process of becoming
> > merged with them."
> >
> > For the majority then, this would become an 'i before e' type of rule:
> > For 'long O', use 'Owe' except before 'Roe', in which case use 'Awe'.
> > This feels unnatural to me.
>
> I think you have it backwards. The NORTH words have always been
> pronounced as THOUGHT + /r/, except in accents where there is no separate
> THOUGHT vowel (that is, THOUGHT = PALM). "Long O" is GOAT, and it's the
> FORCE words that are GOAT + /r/ among people who make this distinction.
>
> So what's happened is that the sound used in unmerged accents for FORCE
> has changed to the one used in all accents for NORTH. That's why it
> makes sense to use the NORTH spelling (Awe+Roe) for merged accents.
>
>
> > On the other hand, what would be the cost of having the majority use
> > 'Owe' + 'Roe' for both NORTH and FORCE?
>
> The fact that for rhotic speakers that don't have THOUGHT = PALM,
> NORTH, FORCE, and THOUGHT have the same vowel (neglecting the /r/ for
> the moment), and that vowel is written Awe.
>
> My dialect is one of these, and for me "foh+rce" and "noh+rth" are
> extremely unnatural renderings of these words.
>
>
> > Couldn't those who distinguish the two still do so by using 'Owe'
> > and 'Awe' as appropriate?
>
> Absolutely.
>
